Comment: Kristi Noem, Nancy Mace and Karoline Leavitt did not invent either the aesthetic or the tactics they employ on social media, Jessica Grose writes in Times Opinion. “Their look is an extreme and specific version of a million other interchangeable influencers. As my newsroom colleague Sandra Garcia noted, ‘Lifestyle influencers exist in an ecosystem that prizes homogeneity,’ because social media algorithms reward it. These algorithms also reward rage baiting, or the deliberate posting of negative content in order to create more engagement and more clicks. Influencing has become a form of female power that is acceptable within conservative communities because it does not threaten the status quo, where women are ultimately subordinate and ornamental.“  Read the full piece [here, for free](https://www.nytimes.com/2025/05/07/opinion/maga-beauty-viral-women.html?unlocked_article_code=1.FU8.NH0y.PxHw27grDyW_&smid=re-nytopinion), even without a Times subscription.

Comment: Well I’ve been looking through the comments, and I’m sure a lot of them are not even located in the US. They seem to be all over Facebook, Fox News, X, and there is no substance to anything they say. It’s a random “what about ___”, an insult to a group, or blind support. There isn’t anything that can change them since they don’t seem to care at all and may actually be doing this for a living (based on a couple pro Trump posts I saw and then they started arguing in hindi for no apparent reason about wages).   It may sound sad but democrats may need to employ similar tactics, inflammatory one-liners and bail. There is a large portion of our population that does not simply have the attention for anything more than a one-line quip. The other option is just playing people’s emotion, specifically anger about the opposing side, which has been shown to have a far greater impact on memories and opinions than promoting one’s own strengths, it’s easier and more effective to just point out people’s flaws
